ground_truth: Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman looks after Neff, relocks the door, and follows him to the elevator. Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him. The night watchman pulls the lever, the doors close, and the elevator rises. The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a little light beyond the glass doors. Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator, crosses the reception room to the doors, and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is filled with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. Neff enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other moving chairs back into position. Neff moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his face and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens the door to reveal three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three desks. Neff enters, switches on the desk lamp, and his head goes far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face. After staying like this for a moment, exhausted, his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand flips the overcoat back, unbuttons his jacket, loosens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He rests for a second, breathing hard with his eyes closed, then fingers a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is blood on it. He wheels himself back to the desk, dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet, some blood-stained and a few clean. He takes a clean one, puts it between his lips, gropes for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, the sound stops, and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Neff strides in past the night sentinel without replying and heads towards the lift. The night sentinel watches after Neff, relocks the entrance, and follows him to the lift. Neff enters the lift appearing pale and worn with agony but maintains an impassive expression as the night sentinel joins him. The night sentinel pulls the lever, the panels close, and the lift ascends. The entrance opens to disclose a small dim reception chamber with a pair of frosted glass panels marked: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE AGENCY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a little light beyond the glass panels. Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the lift, crosses the reception chamber to the panels, and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh level below, which is filled with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business equipment. Neff enters the area from the reception chamber while the twelfth level remains dark and some light gleams up from the eleventh level where two colored women are tidying the offices — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other repositioning chairs. Neff moves away from the railing with a faint grin on his visage and walks past two or three offices towards a glass panel marked with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens the panel to disclose three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records beneath, and telephones on all three desks. Neff enters, switches on the desk lamp, and his head goes far back as his eyes shut with cold sweat showing on his visage. After staying like this for a moment, fatigued, his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand flips the overcoat back, unbuttons his jacket, loosens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He rests for a second, breathing hard with his eyes shut, then fingers a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is blood on it. He wheels himself back to the desk, dumps the loose cigarettes out of the pack, some blood-stained and a few clean. He takes a clean one, puts it between his lips, searches for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, the sound ceases, and the record spins on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In past the night watchman, Neff is walked in by him without being answered and towards the elevator, he is headed by Neff. After Neff, the night watchman looks, the door is relocked by him, and he follows him to the elevator. The elevator is entered by Neff appearing pale and haggard with pain, but a deadpan expression is maintained by him as the night watchman joins. The lever is pulled by the night watchman, the doors are closed, and the elevator is raised. A small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a little light beyond the glass doors, is opened to reveal by the door. Neff is straightened up by himself and the elevator is walked heavily out of by him, to the doors he is crossed by him, and they are pushed open by him. These are led to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is filled with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. From the reception room, the area is entered by Neff while the twelfth floor is remained dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where the offices are cleaned by two colored women — the floor is dry-mopped by one, the chairs are moved back into position by the other. From the railing, Neff is moved away by himself with a faint smile on his face and two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ are walked past by him. By Neff, the door is opened to reveal three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three desks. By Neff, it is entered, the desk lamp is switched on, and by his head, it is gone far back as with cold sweat showing on his face, the eyes are closed by him. Like this for a moment, exhausted, he stays, and slowly, his eyes are opened and they look down at his left shoulder. The overcoat is flipped back by his good hand, his jacket is unbuttoned, his tie and shirt are loosened, which proves to be quite an effort. For a second, he is rested, breathing hard with his eyes closed, then a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket is fingered by him, it is pulled out by him, and on it, he notices there is blood. To the desk, he is wheeled back, the loose cigarettes are dumped out of the packet by him, some blood-stained and a few clean. A clean one is taken by him, between his lips it is put, for a match he gropes, the cigarette is lighted, a deep drag is taken, and through his nose, smoke is let out by him. Toward the dictaphone again, Neff is then pulled by himself while still in the swivel chair, it is reached by him, the horn is lifted off the bracket causing a low buzzing sound to be made by the dictaphone. On the horn, the button switch is pressed by him, the sound is stopped, and on the cylinder, the record is revolved as speaking is begun by him. The dictation is then interrupted by him and on the desk, the horn is laid down.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Neff enters past the night watchman without a word and heads to the elevator. The watchman relocks the door and follows. Neff, pale and in pain, maintains a deadpan expression as they ride up. The elevator opens to a dim reception room with frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE. Neff exits heavily, crosses the room, and opens the doors to a balcony overlooking the eleventh floor filled with desks and machines. Light from below reveals two women cleaning. Neff smiles faintly, walks past offices to a glass door labeled with the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Inside, he finds three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter, a dictaphone, and telephones. Neff switches on a lamp, leans back, and closes his eyes, sweating. He opens his jacket, loosens his tie, and finds blood on his cigarette pack. He dumps the cigarettes, selects a clean one, lights it, and smokes. Neff then moves to the dictaphone, lifts the horn, stops the buzzing, and begins to speak before pausing and setting the horn down.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Neff enters past the night watchman without a word and heads to the elevator. The watchman relocks the door and follows. Neff, pale and in pain, maintains a deadpan look as they ride up. The elevator opens to a dark reception room with frosted glass doors labeled PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY. Neff exits heavily, crosses the room, and opens the doors to a balcony overlooking the eleventh floor filled with desks and machines. Light from below reveals two women cleaning. Neff smiles faintly, walks past offices to a door labeled with his and others' names. Inside are desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter, and a dictaphone. Neff switches on a lamp, closes his eyes, then looks at his left shoulder. He unbuttons his jacket, loosens his tie, and finds blood on his cigarette pack. He dumps the cigarettes, takes a clean one, lights it, and smokes. Neff moves to the dictaphone, lifts the horn, stops the buzzing, and begins to speak, then pauses and lays the horn down.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Neff strides in past the night watchman, choosing not to respond, and makes his way directly towards the elevator. The night watchman, observing Neff's silent passage, secures the door once more and trails behind him to the elevator. Neff steps into the elevator, his appearance notably pale and haggard, clearly suffering from pain, yet he manages to maintain a stoic, deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him inside. The night watchman then pulls the lever, causing the doors to close, and the elevator begins its ascent. When the doors part, they reveal a small, dimly lit reception room. This room features a pair of frosted glass doors, prominently labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a faint light emanating from beyond the glass doors. Neff straightens his posture and, with a heavy gait, exits the elevator, traverses the reception room, and pushes open the doors. These doors lead to a balcony that encircles the area, providing a view of the eleventh floor below, which is bustling with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and various business machines. Neff enters this area from the reception room, while the twelfth floor remains shrouded in darkness, with some light filtering up from the eleventh floor where two women of color are diligently cleaning the offices—one is dry-mopping the floor, while the other is repositioning chairs. Neff moves away from the railing, a faint smile playing on his lips, and proceeds past two or three offices until he reaches a glass door marked with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens this door to reveal an office space containing three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall, complete with a rack of records beneath it, and telephones on each of the three desks. Neff enters, switches on the desk lamp, and leans his head far back, his eyes closing as cold sweat becomes visible on his face. After remaining in this position for a moment, clearly exhausted, his eyes slowly open and focus on his left shoulder. With his good hand, he flips back his overcoat, unbuttons his jacket, and loosens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He pauses for a moment, breathing heavily with his eyes closed, then reaches for a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices blood on it. He wheels himself back to the desk, empties the loose cigarettes from the packet, some stained with blood and a few clean. He selects a clean one, places it between his lips, searches for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep drag, and exhales the smoke through his nose. Neff then maneuvers himself toward the dictaphone once more while still seated in the swivel chair, reaches it, and lifts the horn off the bracket, causing the dictaphone to emit a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, silencing the sound, and the record begins to revolve on the cylinder as he starts to speak. He then pauses the dictation and gently lays the horn down on the desk.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Neff makes his entrance, striding past the night watchman with a purposeful air, choosing to remain silent and not engage in any sort of verbal exchange. Instead, he directs his focus and energy into moving straight towards the elevator. Behind him, the night watchman observes Neff's quiet passage with a vigilant eye, ensuring the door is secured once again, and follows after him to the elevator. Neff steps into the elevator, his physical appearance increasingly pale and visibly haggard, indicative of the pain he is suffering. Nonetheless, he maintains a stoic composure, his expression unwavering and deadpan, as the night watchman enters the elevator to stand by his side. The night watchman then proceeds to pull the lever, which sets the doors in motion, causing them to close, initiating the elevator's ascent. 

As the elevator reaches its destination and the doors slide open, they unveil a small, dimly lit room designated for reception. This reception area features a set of frosted glass doors, conspicuously labeled with the text: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a faint light emanating from the space beyond these glass doors. Neff adjusts his posture, straightening his back, and with a slow, measured gait, steps out of the elevator. He traverses the expanse of the reception room and pushes open the glass doors. These doors open up to a balcony that wraps around the area, providing a view down to the eleventh floor below, which is bustling with the activity of desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and an array of business machines. Neff moves into this busy area from the reception room, while the twelfth floor remains enveloped in shadow, with only some light filtering up from the eleventh floor. Here, two women of color are diligently at work, cleaning the offices—one is engaged in dry-mopping the floor, while the other is busy repositioning chairs. 

Neff steps away from the railing, a faint smile playing on his lips, as he moves past two or three offices until he arrives at a glass door marked with the number twenty-seven alongside the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens this door, revealing an office space occupied by three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, and a dictaphone affixed to the wall, complete with a rack of records neatly arranged beneath it, and telephones strategically placed on each of the three desks. Neff enters this office space, switches on the desk lamp, and leans his head far back, closing his eyes as cold sweat visibly forms on his face. After holding this position for a brief moment, clearly showing signs of exhaustion, his eyes gradually reopen and focus intently on his left shoulder. Using his good hand, he methodically flips back his overcoat, unbuttons his jacket, and takes the effort to loosen his tie and shirt. He pauses, breathing heavily with his eyes closed, then reaches into his shirt pocket for a pack of cigarettes, pulls it out, and notices blood staining it. He wheels himself back to the desk, empties the loose cigarettes from the packet, noting that some are stained with blood while a few remain clean. He carefully selects a clean cigarette, places it gingerly between his lips, searches for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep and satisfying drag, and exhales the smoke slowly through his nose. Neff then maneuvers himself towards the dictaphone once more, while still seated in the swivel chair, reaches it, and lifts the horn from the bracket, prompting the dictaphone to emit a low, steady buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, silencing the sound, and the record begins its process of revolving on the cylinder as he starts to speak. He subsequently pauses in his dictation and gently lays the horn down on the desk.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Neff strides purposefully past the night watchman, who stands at his post, without offering a word or glance, and makes his way directly toward the elevator. The night watchman, momentarily watching Neff's retreating figure, proceeds to relock the door with a practiced motion and then follows Neff to the elevator. Neff steps into the elevator, his face betraying a pallor and haggardness that suggest deep pain, yet he maintains a stoic, deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him inside. The night watchman reaches for the lever, pulls it with a firm grip, causing the elevator doors to slide shut, and the elevator begins its ascent. As the elevator comes to a halt, the doors part to reveal a small, dimly lit reception room, where a pair of frosted glass doors stand prominently labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a faint glow emanating from beyond the glass. Neff straightens his posture, steps heavily out of the elevator, and crosses the reception room with deliberate steps until he reaches the doors, which he pushes open with a determined motion. These doors lead to a balcony that encircles the space, offering a view of the eleventh floor below, bustling with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. Neff enters this area from the reception room, noting that the twelfth floor remains shrouded in darkness while a soft light filters up from the eleventh floor, where two women are diligently cleaning the offices—one methodically dry-mopping the floor, the other repositioning chairs with care. Neff moves away from the railing, a faint smile playing on his lips, and walks past two or three offices until he reaches a glass door marked with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. He opens the door to reveal an office space containing three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records beneath it, and telephones on each desk. Neff enters the room, switches on the desk lamp, and leans his head far back, closing his eyes as cold sweat beads on his face. After a moment of exhaustion, his eyes slowly open, and he glances down at his left shoulder. With his good hand, he flips back his overcoat, unbuttons his jacket, and loosens his tie and shirt, each movement requiring considerable effort. He pauses to catch his breath, eyes closed, then reaches into his shirt pocket to finger a pack of cigarettes, pulling it out only to notice blood staining it. He wheels himself back to the desk, empties the loose cigarettes from the packet, some marked with blood, others clean. Selecting a clean one, he places it between his lips, fumbles for a match, lights the cigarette, and inhales deeply, exhaling smoke through his nose. Neff then maneuvers himself toward the dictaphone while still seated in the swivel chair, reaches it, and lifts the horn off its bracket, prompting the dictaphone to emit a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, silencing the buzz, and the record begins to revolve on the cylinder as he starts to speak. He then pauses his dictation and gently lays the horn down on the desk.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Neff enters the building, bypassing the night watchman, and heads to the elevator, where the watchman joins him. Despite appearing pale and haggard, Neff maintains a deadpan expression as the elevator ascends. Upon reaching the small, dark reception room, Neff straightens up and proceeds through the frosted glass doors labeled PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY, revealing a balcony overlooking the eleventh floor. He observes two women cleaning below, then moves past several offices to a glass door marked with his and his colleagues' names. Inside, Neff switches on a desk lamp, revealing his exhaustion and cold sweat. He loosens his clothing with difficulty, discovering blood on his cigarette pack. After discarding the stained cigarettes, he lights a clean one and takes a deep drag. Neff then maneuvers to the dictaphone, lifts the horn, and begins to speak, only to pause and lay the horn down on the desk.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Neff, a weary insurance agent at the Pacific All-Risk Insurance Company, walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman, who has known Neff for years and is used to his late-night visits, looks after Neff, relocks the door, and follows him to the elevator. Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him. The night watchman, a retired police officer, pulls the lever, the doors close, and the elevator rises. The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, illuminated only by a little light beyond the glass doors. Neff, despite his discomfort, straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator, crosses the reception room to the doors, and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is filled with desks, typewriters from the early 20th century, filing cabinets, and business machines essential for daily operations. Neff enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women, part of the night cleaning staff, are cleaning the offices — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other moving chairs back into position. Neff moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his face, recalling the camaraderie of the daytime staff, and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens the door to reveal three desks, filing cabinets filled with client files, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three desks. Neff enters, switches on the desk lamp, and his head goes far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face. After staying like this for a moment, exhausted from the day's tension, his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand flips the overcoat back, unbuttons his jacket, loosens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He rests for a second, breathing hard with his eyes closed, then fingers a pack of Lucky Strike cigarettes in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is blood on it. He wheels himself back to the desk, dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet, some blood-stained and a few clean. He takes a clean one, puts it between his lips, gropes for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound similar to those used in the 1940s for recording office dictation. He presses the button switch on the horn, the sound stops, and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. He wheels himself back to the desk dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet some bloodstained and a few clean. He takes a clean one puts it between his lips gropes for a match lights. the cigarette takes a deep drag and let us smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair reaches it lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn. the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman looks after. Neff relocks the door and follows him to the elevator. Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him. The night watchman pulls the lever. the doors close and the elevator rises. The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled PACIFIC ALLRISK INSURANCE COMPANY  FOUNDED 1906  MAIN OFFICE. with a little light beyond the glass doors Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator crosses the reception room to the doors and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around overlooking the eleventh floor below which is filled with desks typewriters filing cabinets and business machines. Neff enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark. and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is drymopping the floor the other moving chairs back into position. Neff moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his face and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twentyseven and the names. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. HENRY B ANDERSON WALTER NEFF LOUIS L SCHWARTZ. Neff opens the door to reveal three desks filing cabinets a typewriter on a stand a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath and telephones on all three desks. Neff enters switches on the desk lamp and his head goes far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face. After staying like this for a moment exhausted his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand flips the overcoat back unbuttons his jacket loosens his tie and shirt which proves to be quite an effort. He rests for a second breathing hard with his eyes closed then fingers a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket pulls it out and notices there is blood on it. He wheels himself back to the desk dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet some bloodstained and a few clean. He takes a clean one puts it between his lips gropes for a match lights. the cigarette takes a deep drag and let us smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair reaches it lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn. the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman looks after. Neff relocks the door and follows him to the elevator. Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him. The night watchman pulls the lever. the doors close and the elevator rises. He wheels himself back to the desk dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet some bloodstained and a few clean. He takes a clean one puts it between his lips gropes for a match lights. the cigarette takes a deep drag and let us smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair reaches it lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. He presses the button switch on the horn. the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman looks after. He presses the button switch on the horn. the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The squirrel walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator. The night watchman looks after the squirrel, relocks the door, and follows it to the elevator. The squirrel enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins it. The night watchman pulls the lever, the doors close, and the elevator rises. The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a little light beyond the glass doors. The squirrel straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator, crosses the reception room to the doors, and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is filled with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. The squirrel enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other moving chairs back into position. The squirrel moves away from the railing with a faint smile on its face and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. The squirrel opens the door to reveal three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three desks. The squirrel enters, switches on the desk lamp, and its head goes far back as its eyes close with cold sweat showing on its face. After staying like this for a moment, exhausted, its eyes open slowly and look down at its left shoulder. Its good hand flips the overcoat back, unbuttons its jacket, loosens its tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. It rests for a second, breathing hard with its eyes closed, then fingers a pack of cigarettes in its shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is blood on it. It wheels itself back to the desk, dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet, some blood-stained and a few clean. It takes a clean one, puts it between its lips, gropes for a match, lights the cigarette, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through its nose. The squirrel then pulls itself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. It presses the button switch on the horn, the sound stops, and the record revolves on the cylinder as it begins to speak. It then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Neff walks in past the night guard without answering and heads towards the escalator. The night guard looks after Neff, relocks the gate, and follows him to the escalator. Neff steps onto the escalator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night guard joins him. The night guard presses the button, the rails move, and the escalator ascends. The top reveals a small dim lounge area with a pair of frosted glass windows labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK TRAVEL AGENCY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN BRANCH, with a little light beyond the glass windows. Neff straightens up and walks heavily off the escalator, crosses the lounge area to the windows, and pushes them open. These lead to a passageway that runs all the way around, overlooking the tenth floor below, which is filled with benches, typewriters, filing boxes, and office equipment. Neff enters the area from the lounge area while the eleventh floor remains dark and some light shines up from the tenth floor where two colored women are tidying the workspace — one is sweeping the floor, the other rearranging chairs. Neff moves away from the ledge with a faint smile on his face and walks past two or three booths towards a glass window labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff opens the window to reveal three benches, filing boxes, a typewriter on a cart, a gramophone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and phones on all three benches. Neff enters, switches on the desk lamp, and his head tilts far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face. After staying like this for a moment, exhausted, his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder. His good hand flips the trench coat back, unbuttons his vest, loosens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He rests for a second, breathing hard with his eyes closed, then fingers a pack of chewing gum in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is ink on it. He wheels himself back to the bench, dumps the loose gum out of the packet, some ink-stained and a few clean. He takes a clean piece, puts it between his lips, fumbles for a lighter, ignites the gum, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through his nose. Neff then pulls himself toward the gramophone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the horn off the bracket causing the gramophone to make a low humming sound. He presses the button switch on the horn, the sound stops, and the record spins on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then interrupts the narration and lays down the horn on the bench.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Neff strolls in past the night watchman without acknowledging and veers towards the elevator. The night watchman glances after Neff, secures the door, and shadows him to the elevator. Neff steps into the elevator appearing weary and fatigued with discomfort but holds a neutral expression as the night watchman accompanies him. The night watchman turns the lever, the doors shut, and the elevator descends. The door opens to disclose a small dim reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-RISK INSURANCE COMPANY - FOUNDED 1906 - MAIN OFFICE, with a faint glow beyond the glass doors. Neff loosens up and stumbles heavily out of the elevator, traverses the reception room to the doors, and slides them open. These lead to a platform that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is adorned with desks, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. Neff exits the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other shifting chairs into place. Neff drifts away from the railing with a faint grin on his face and glides past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twenty-seven and the names: HENRY B. ANDERSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. SCHWARTZ. Neff swings the door to reveal three desks, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three desks. Neff slips in, flicks on the desk lamp, and his head tilts far back as his eyes shut with cold sweat appearing on his face. After pausing like this for a moment, fatigued, his eyes gradually open and gaze down at his left shoulder. His good hand twists the overcoat back, snaps his jacket, tightens his tie and shirt, which proves to be quite an effort. He pauses for a second, inhaling deeply with his eyes closed, then fumbles a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket, plucks it out, and observes there is blood on it. He pushes himself back to the desk, spills the loose cigarettes out of the packet, some blood-stained and a few intact. He selects a clean one, places it between his lips, fumbles for a match, ignites the cigarette, takes a deep puff, and lets smoke trail out through his nose. Neff then draws himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, raises the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to emit a low humming sound. He taps the button switch on the horn, the sound ceases, and the record spins on the cylinder as he begins to speak. He then halts the dictation and rests the horn on the desk.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Glove walks in past the garden gnome without answering and heads towards the trampoline. The garden gnome looks after Glove, relocks the suitcase, and follows it to the trampoline. Glove enters the trampoline appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the garden gnome joins it. The garden gnome pulls the rope, the curtains close, and the trampoline rises. The curtain opens to reveal a small dark concert hall with a pair of frosted glass windows labeled: ATLANTIC NO-RISK BAKERY - FOUNDED 1912 - MAIN KITCHEN, with a little light beyond the glass windows. Glove straightens up and walks heavily out of the trampoline, crosses the concert hall to the windows, and pushes them open. These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around, overlooking the eleventh floor below, which is filled with sofas, typewriters, filing cabinets, and business machines. Glove enters the area from the concert hall while the twelfth floor remains dark and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored balloons are cleaning the theaters — one is dry-mopping the floor, the other moving stools back into position. Glove moves away from the railing with a faint smile on its face and walks past two or three theaters towards a glass window labeled with the number forty-two and the names: SAMUEL Q. BRADSHAW, CARLTON GLOVE, GERALD J. SPINKS. Glove opens the window to reveal three sofas, filing cabinets, a typewriter on a stand, a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath, and telephones on all three sofas. Glove enters, switches on the lamp, and its head goes far back as its eyes close with cold sweat showing on its face. After staying like this for a moment, exhausted, its eyes open slowly and look down at its left elbow. Its good foot flips the trench coat back, unbuttons its sweater, loosens its necklace and blouse, which proves to be quite an effort. It rests for a second, breathing hard with its eyes closed, then fingers a pack of chew toys in its blouse pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is paint on it. It wheels itself back to the sofa, dumps the loose chew toys out of the packet, some paint-stained and a few clean. It takes a clean one, puts it between its lips, gropes for a candle, lights the chew toy, takes a deep drag, and lets smoke out through its ears. Glove then pulls itself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the bell off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound. It presses the switch on the bell, the sound stops, and the record revolves on the cylinder as it begins to speak. It then interrupts the dictation and lays down the bell on the sofa.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Riley gallops in past the night janitor without acknowledging and dives towards the escalator. The night janitor observes Riley, secures the door, and ambles after him to the escalator. Riley approaches the escalator appearing flushed and exhausted with discomfort but maintains a neutral expression as the night janitor joins him. The night janitor pushes the lever, the doors shut, and the escalator descends. The door opens to reveal a small dim waiting room with a pair of frosted glass panels labeled: ATLANTIC NO-RISK BANKING COMPANY - ESTABLISHED 1906 - MAIN BRANCH, with a faint light beyond the glass panels. Riley straightens up and trudges heavily out of the escalator, crosses the waiting room to the panels, and pulls them open. These lead to a corridor that runs all the way around, overlooking the tenth floor below, which is filled with tables, computers, filing drawers, and office gadgets. Riley enters the area from the waiting room while the eleventh floor remains dim and some light shines up from the tenth floor where two colored men are tidying the offices — one is wiping the windows, the other rearranging chairs. Riley moves away from the railing with a faint grin on his face and shuffles past two or three rooms towards a glass door labeled with the number thirty-one and the names: JACK R. JOHNSON, RILEY ADAMS, SAMUEL S. BURTON. Riley opens the door to reveal three tables, filing drawers, a laptop on a stand, a microphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a row of tapes underneath, and telephones on all three tables. Riley enters, flicks on the desk lamp, and his head leans far back as his eyes close with cold sweat appearing on his face. After staying like this for a moment, tired, his eyes open slowly and gaze down at his right elbow. His good hand flips the coat back, unbuttons his sweater, loosens his collar and shirt, which proves to be quite an ordeal. He rests for a second, panting with his eyes closed, then fishes a pack of gum in his shirt pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is ink on it. He rolls himself back to the table, spills the loose gum out of the packet, some ink-stained and a few clean. He takes a clean one, places it between his lips, fumbles for a lighter, lights the gum, takes a deep breath, and lets air out through his mouth. Riley then wheels himself toward the microphone again while still in the swivel chair, reaches it, lifts the mouthpiece off the hook causing the microphone to make a low humming sound. He presses the button switch on the mouthpiece, the sound stops, and the tape spins on the reel as he begins to recite. He then pauses the recitation and lays down the mouthpiece on the table.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Neff strolls past the day gardener without greeting and meanders towards the escalator. The day gardener gazes after Neff, secures the gate, and trails him to the escalator. Neff steps onto the escalator appearing bright and cheerful with delight but maintains a cheerful expression as the day gardener accompanies him. The day gardener presses a button, the steps begin to move, and the escalator descends. The opening reveals a large bright waiting area with a pair of clear glass doors labeled: PACIFIC ALL-FUN PARK - ESTABLISHED 1906 - MAIN ENTRANCE, with a lot of light beyond the glass doors. Neff bends down and skips lightly out of the escalator, crosses the waiting area to the doors, and nudges them open. These lead to a gallery that extends all the way around, overlooking the second floor below, which is filled with benches, pianos, filing shelves, and musical equipment. Neff steps into the space from the waiting area while the third floor remains bright and some shadows move up from the second floor where two elderly men are rearranging the artifacts — one is dusting the shelves, the other placing books back into position. Neff moves toward the railing with a broad grin on his face and saunters past two or three rooms towards a wooden door labeled with the number sixty-four and the names: HENRY B. JOHNSON, WALTER NEFF, LOUIS L. BRADFORD. Neff slides the door to reveal three armchairs, filing shelves, a piano on a stage, a phonograph on a mobile stand against the wall with a stack of records underneath, and radios on all three tables. Neff enters, switches on the ceiling lamp, and his head tips forward as his eyes open with warm tears showing in his eyes. After staying like this for a moment, relieved, his eyes close slowly and gaze at his right foot. His weak hand pulls the jacket forward, buttons his vest, tightens his belt and pants, which proves to be quite a feat. He pauses for a second, sighing loudly with his eyes open, then fiddles with a pack of candies in his coat pocket, extracts it, and notices there is mud on it. He shuffles himself to the table, spills the loose candies out of the packet, some mud-covered and a few clean. He picks a clean one, puts it between his fingers, fumbles for a lighter, ignites the candy, takes a deep whiff, and lets air out through his ears. Neff then rolls himself toward the phonograph again while still in the rocking chair, reaches it, lifts the needle off the tarp causing the phonograph to make a loud humming sound. He pushes the lever on the needle, the sound ceases, and the record spins on the platter as he begins to sing. He then stops the singing and lays down the needle on the chair.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Gorilla tiptoes in past the zookeeper without singing and skips towards the escalator. The zookeeper gazes after Gorilla, chains the gate, and skates behind him to the escalator. Gorilla hops onto the escalator appearing colorful and sprightly with joy but maintains a jubilant expression as the zookeeper joins him. The zookeeper yanks the rope, the gates shut, and the escalator descends. The gate opens to reveal a vast bright ballroom with a pair of stained glass windows labeled: ATLANTIC NO-HARM DANCE ACADEMY - ESTABLISHED 1806 - CENTRAL STUDIO, with a small bell beyond the glass windows. Gorilla stretches out and hops lightly out of the escalator, crosses the ballroom to the windows, and swings them open. These lead to a terrace that runs all the way around, overlooking the fifth floor below, which is filled with pianos, trombones, trumpets, and percussion instruments. Gorilla bounces into the area from the ballroom while the sixth floor remains bright and some bells chime up from the fifth floor where two spotted dogs are organizing the studios — one is dry-painting the walls, the other rearranging drums back into place. Gorilla dances away from the ledge with a broad grin on his face and skips past two or three studios towards a wooden window labeled with the number seventy-two and the names: MICHAEL B. BAKER, CHARLIE GORILLA, SAM S. LEMON. Gorilla flings the window to reveal three pianos, percussion instruments, a trombone on a stand, a flute on a fixed stand against the wall with a row of sheet music underneath, and tambourines on all three pianos. Gorilla cartwheels, switches on the chandelier, and his feet go way up as his hands close with warm sweat showing on his torso. After staying like this for a moment, excited, his hands open slowly and look down at his right ankle. His nimble foot flips the sneaker back, unlaces his sandal, unzips his vest, which proves to be quite a perplexity. He rests for a second, sighing loudly with his hands closed, then caresses a pack of gum in his vest pocket, pulls it out, and notices there is ink on it. He shuffles himself back to the piano, spills the loose gum out of the packet, some ink-smeared and a few clean. He picks a clean one, puts it between his teeth, pats for a lighter, ignites the gum, takes a deep blow, and lets music out through his ears. Gorilla then glides himself toward the flute again while still in the spinning chair, reaches it, lifts the button off the bracket causing the flute to make a high whistling sound. He taps the string key on the button, the sound silences, and the sheet music rotates on the stand as he begins to hum. He then pauses the humming and sets down the button on the piano.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Neff walks past the night watchman to the elevator, appearing pale and haggard but maintaining a deadpan expression. The elevator takes him to a dark reception room leading to the Pacific All-Risk Insurance Company’s main office. On the eleventh floor, Neff sees two women cleaning and moves away with a faint smile. He approaches a glass door marked with his name, enters, and turns on a desk lamp. Exhausted, Neff struggles to unbutton his jacket and notices blood on a cigarette pack. He lights a clean cigarette, exhales deeply, then moves to the dictaphone, initiating a recording before pausing to lay the horn down on the desk.

reaches it lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound  HENRY B ANDERSON WALTER NEFF LOUIS L SCHWARTZ  The night watchman pulls the lever the doors close and the elevator rises  His good hand flips the overcoat back unbuttons his jacket loosens his tie and shirt which proves to be quite an effort  He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is drymopping the floor the other moving chairs back into position  with a little light beyond the glass doors Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator crosses the reception room to the doors and pushes them open  He rests for a second breathing hard with his eyes closed then fingers a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket pulls it out and notices there is blood on it  The night watchman looks after  the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak  Neff opens the door to reveal three desks filing cabinets a typewriter on a stand a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath and telephones on all three desks  Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him  Neff relocks the door and follows him to the elevator  He presses the button switch on the horn  Neff moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his face and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twentyseven and the names  Neff enters switches on the desk lamp and his head goes far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face  The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled PACIFIC ALLRISK INSURANCE COMPANY  FOUNDED 1906  MAIN OFFICE  Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator  Neff enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark  He takes a clean one puts it between his lips gropes for a match lights the cigarette takes a deep drag and lets smoke out through his nose  After staying like this for a moment exhausted his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: Neff opens the door to reveal three desks filing cabinets a typewriter on a stand a dictaphone on a fixed stand against the wall with a rack of records underneath and telephones on all three desks  Neff enters switches on the desk lamp and his head goes far back as his eyes close with cold sweat showing on his face  After staying like this for a moment exhausted his eyes open slowly and look down at his left shoulder  His good hand flips the overcoat back unbuttons his jacket loosens his tie and shirt which proves to be quite an effort  He rests for a second breathing hard with his eyes closed then fingers a pack of cigarettes in his shirt pocket pulls it out and notices there is blood on it  He wheels himself back to the desk dumps the loose cigarettes out of the packet some bloodstained and a few clean  He takes a clean one puts it between his lips gropes for a match lights the cigarette takes a deep drag and lets smoke out through his nose  Neff then pulls himself toward the dictaphone again while still in the swivel chair reaches it lifts the horn off the bracket causing the dictaphone to make a low buzzing sound  He presses the button switch on the horn  the sound stops and the record revolves on the cylinder as he begins to speak  He then interrupts the dictation and lays down the horn on the desk Neff walks in past the night watchman without answering and heads towards the elevator  The night watchman looks after  Neff relocks the door and follows him to the elevator  Neff enters the elevator appearing pale and haggard with pain but maintains a deadpan expression as the night watchman joins him  The night watchman pulls the lever the doors close and the elevator rises  The door opens to reveal a small dark reception room with a pair of frosted glass doors labeled PACIFIC ALLRISK INSURANCE COMPANY  FOUNDED 1906  MAIN OFFICE  with a little light beyond the glass doors Neff straightens up and walks heavily out of the elevator crosses the reception room to the doors and pushes them open  These lead to a balcony that runs all the way around overlooking the eleventh floor below which is filled with desks typewriters filing cabinets and business machines  Neff enters the area from the reception room while the twelfth floor remains dark  and some light shines up from the eleventh floor where two colored women are cleaning the offices — one is drymopping the floor the other moving chairs back into position  Neff moves away from the railing with a faint smile on his face and walks past two or three offices towards a glass door labeled with the number twentyseven and the names  HENRY B ANDERSON WALTER NEFF LOUIS L SCHWARTZ
